articles.headline: Senate Democrats Foil Obama on Asia Trade Deal
articles.snippet: A vote halted consideration of legislation granting President Obama “fast track” power to complete a major trade accord with 11 nations in the Pacific Rim.
articles.abstract: A vote halted consideration of legislation granting President Obama “fast track” power to complete a major trade accord with 11 nations in the Pacific Rim.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senate Democrats on Tuesday blocked consideration of giving President Obama power to accelerate a broad trade accord with Asia, a rebuke that the president helped bring on himself.

articles.headline: More in School, but Not Learning
articles.snippet: Globally, more children than ever are attending school, but some experts say high-quality education has proved elusive. The solution will be expensive.
articles.abstract: Globally, more children than ever are attending school, but some experts say high-quality education has proved elusive. The solution will be expensive.
articles.lead_paragraph: A quarter of a century ago, barely half the children of primary school age in sub-Saharan Africa were enrolled in school. By 2012 the share was 78 percent. In South Asia, primary school enrollment jumped to 94 percent from 75 percent over the same period.

articles.headline: Owner of Anonymous Hackers-for-Hire Site Steps Forward
articles.snippet: Charles Tendell, a war veteran who owns a consulting firm in Denver, says the site, Hacker’s List, grew faster than he anticipated.
articles.abstract: Charles Tendell, a war veteran who owns a consulting firm in Denver, says the site, Hacker’s List, grew faster than he anticipated.
articles.lead_paragraph: He calls himself an ethical hacker who helps companies and individuals fight back against the bad guys operating online. Over the years, Charles Tendell also has emerged as a commentator in the news media about the threat posed by overseas hackers and is a former co-host of an online radio show about security.

articles.headline: For Verizon and AOL, Mobile Is a Magic Word
articles.snippet: The Verizon-AOL deal is just the latest corporate reaction to a staggering shift in the way people across the globe get their news and entertainment.
articles.abstract: The Verizon-AOL deal is just the latest corporate reaction to a staggering shift in the way people across the globe get their news and entertainment.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a memo to employees after announcing that Verizon Communications would buy his company for $4.4 billion, Tim Armstrong, AOL’s chief executive, offered a rhapsodic hymn on a single subject: mobile.

articles.headline: London Real Estate Sizzles Off Campus
articles.snippet: Investors are betting that a surge in international students will increase the imbalance in the supply and demand in student housing.
articles.abstract: Investors are betting that a surge in international students will increase the imbalance in the supply and demand in student housing.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Joyce Ge, a student from China who is studying business management at King’s College, pays 880 pounds a month, or $1,310, to live in a pint-size, stylish studio apartment in the far reaches of east London, in a building with roof decks gazing toward the distant city skyline. Her rent covers water and electricity, as well as Wi-Fi and cleaning of common spaces every two weeks.

articles.headline: Inspectors in Syria Find Traces of Banned Military Chemicals
articles.snippet: The discovery came as Syrian government forces were being accused of continuing to bombard insurgent-held areas with chlorine bombs.
articles.abstract: The discovery came as Syrian government forces were being accused of continuing to bombard insurgent-held areas with chlorine bombs.
articles.lead_paragraph: International inspectors have found traces of banned toxic chemicals in at least three military locations in Syria, four diplomats and officials said, less than two years after President Bashar al-Assad agreed to dismantle the country’s chemical arsenal.
articles.byline: By Somini Sengupta, Marlise Simons and Anne Barnard

articles.headline: Facebook Begins Testing Instant Articles From News Publishers
articles.snippet: The social network will host articles directly on its site instead of linking to them, potentially undermining news sites and apps.
articles.abstract: The social network will host articles directly on its site instead of linking to them, potentially undermining news sites and apps.
articles.lead_paragraph: MENLO PARK, Calif. — Facebook’s long-rumored plan to directly host articles from news organizations will start on Wednesday, concluding months of delicate negotiations between the Internet giant and publishers that covet its huge audience but fear its growing power.
articles.byline: By Vindu Goel and Ravi Somaiya

articles.headline: Amtrak Train Derailed Going 106 M.P.H. on Sharp Curve; at Least 7 Killed
articles.snippet: The Amtrak train that derailed in Philadelphia on Tuesday night was traveling at a speed twice the speed limit on that stretch of track, according to the National Transportation Safety Board.
articles.abstract: The Amtrak train that derailed in Philadelphia on Tuesday night was traveling at a speed twice the speed limit on that stretch of track, according to the National Transportation Safety Board.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — An engineer jammed on the emergency brakes just seconds before Tuesday’s fatal Amtrak derailment, but the train — traveling at 106 miles an hour, more than twice the speed limit — slowed only slightly, federal authorities said, before hurtling off its tracks, killing at least seven people and injuring more than 200.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg, Jad Mouawad and Emma G. Fitzsimmons

articles.headline: Mixing Cuisines, Mexicue Moves Beyond the Food Truck
articles.snippet: With three restaurants in New York, David Schillace and Thomas Kelly plan to open two more each year, taking some cues from Shake Shack and Chipotle.
articles.abstract: With three restaurants in New York, David Schillace and Thomas Kelly plan to open two more each year, taking some cues from Shake Shack and Chipotle.
articles.lead_paragraph: When David Schillace told his friends and family in 2010 that he planned to quit his six-figure-salary job in sales and marketing, cash in his 401(k) retirement plan and start a new career selling a blend of Mexican and barbecue food out of a truck on the streets of Manhattan, there was stunned silence. Then came the tears.

articles.headline: Toyota and Nissan Recall 6.5 Million More Vehicles Over Takata Airbags
articles.snippet: The recalls included more recent models than the companies had previously said needed fixing.
articles.abstract: The recalls included more recent models than the companies had previously said needed fixing.
articles.lead_paragraph: For months, the problem of defective airbags made by the Japanese supplier Takata has festered in the auto industry as recalls have mounted and automakers have searched for the reason that the airbags can explode violently, sending pieces of metal into the cabin.
articles.byline: By Hiroko Tabuchi and Jonathan Soble

articles.headline: Nelson Peltz’s Slate Fails to Win DuPont Board Seats
articles.snippet: DuPont beat back a boardroom challenge at its annual shareholder meeting, one of the rare times that a fight with an activist investor has gone to a vote.
articles.abstract: DuPont beat back a boardroom challenge at its annual shareholder meeting, one of the rare times that a fight with an activist investor has gone to a vote.
articles.lead_paragraph: A stalwart of corporate America scored a victory against shareholder activism on Wednesday as DuPont defeated a corporate governance challenge by the billionaire Nelson Peltz.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Vatican to Recognize Palestinian State in New Treaty
articles.snippet: The Vatican said in a statement that the treaty would be signed in the near future. Israeli officials said they were disappointed by the designation.
articles.abstract: The Vatican said in a statement that the treaty would be signed in the near future. Israeli officials said they were disappointed by the designation.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The Vatican announced Wednesday that it would soon sign a treaty that includes recognition of the “state of Palestine,” lending significant symbolic weight to an intensifying Palestinian push for international support for sovereignty that bypasses the paralyzed negotiations with Israel.
articles.byline: By Jodi Rudoren and Diaa Hadid
